document.text: Does regional variation in wage levels identify the
effects of a national minimum wage?
This paper examines the identification assumptions underlying estimators of the
causal effects of national minimum wages on employment and wages, such as the "fraction affected" and "effective minimum wage" designs. Specifically, I conduct a series of
simulation exercises to investigate whether these assumptions hold in the context of particular economic models used as data-generating processes. I find that, in many cases,
the fraction affected design exhibits small biases that lead to inflated rejection rates of
the true causal effect. These biases can be larger in the presence of either trends in the

dispersion of wages within regions, equilibrium responses to the minimum wage, or violations of the parallel trends assumption. I propose two diagnostic exercises to complement the standard test for differential pre-trends commonly used to validate this design.
For the effective minimum wage design, I show that while the identification assumptions
) are crucial, they are not sufficient for unbiased estimation.
Under various economically plausible scenarios, estimators within this framework can
exhibit significant biases that are difficult to diagnose through specification tests.
Department of Economics, UCLA and NBER. Contact information: haanwinckel@econ.ucla.edu
This paper benefited from conversations with Maurizio Mazzocco and Yotam Shem-tov.
Labor economists employ diverse methodological approaches to quantify the impact of minimum wages on employment and wage distribution. In some cases, minimum wages are
raised selectively, creating a quasi-experimental setting where researchers can utilize a differencein-differences design by comparing "treated" and "control" regions. But often, the researcher
change in the minimum wage. In those cases, they can employ empirical designs that leverage regional wage variations to construct continuous measures of
treatment. These designs assume that the minimum wage’s effects are more pronounced
where it has more “bite” into the wage distribution. They include “fraction affected” regressions following
). These techniques have been applied in papers published by leading economic journals to study national minimum wages in contexts such as Mexico (
This paper examines the identification assumptions underlying those econometric approaches
when there is no nominal minimum wage variation across regions. Specifically, it presents
and discusses a series of simulation exercises designed to investigate whether fraction affected and effective minimum wage designs can accurately capture the causal effects of the
minimum wage on employment and wages, as predicted by specific economic models.
I study three classes of economic models. The first is the “canonical” competitive model,
where a representative firm combines two types of labor using a constant elasticity of substitution (CES) production function. In this model, the minimum wage leads to disemployment
and endogenous responses in returns to skill. The second model disregards endogenous
equilibrium responses but features a more flexible distribution of latent worker productivities, enabling exploration of diverse economic scenarios. It also incorporates mechanical
wage increases for certain workers and a “spike” in the distribution of log wages. The third
for minimum wage effects. These pathways include worker reallocation from low- to highwage firms and changes in the assignment of workers to tasks within firms. Additionally,
this model replicates the original Brazilian data effectively, capturing variations in the wage
distribution across regions and over time (including the minimum wage spike), as well as the
contributions of firm wage premiums and firm-worker sorting patterns to wage inequality.
Using these models as data-generating processes, I test the performance of the estimators in
models with two periods, where the national minimum wage increases between the periods.
In the "fraction affected" regressions, the primary independent variable is the share of workers affected by the change in the minimum wage, interacted with a "post" period indicator.
In the "effective minimum wage" design, the key independent variables are the difference
between the log minimum wage and the median wage, along with its squared value. Both
regression approaches include fixed effects for regions and time. Alternative versions of
the estimators are also tested, including a variant of the fraction affected design using the
"Gap measure" as the treatment intensity variable (
), and an alternative effective minimum wage approach based on a higher quantile of
A series of simulation exercises reveals that the fraction affected design exhibits small biases even in cases where optimal performance might be expected, such as when the latent log
wage distribution solely differs between regions due to a “location” parameter, and the minimum wage is the only time-varying factor. These small biases result in confidence intervals
rejecting the true causal effect more frequently than the desired confidence level.
The simulations also show that biases are larger in three scenarios. First, when there are
trends in the dispersion of log wages, even if they affect all regions uniformly. Second, when
there are violations of the parallel trends assumption, even concerning outcomes that are
not commonly tested (such as the dispersion of latent worker productivities within regions).
Third, when the minimum wage induces substantial changes in returns to skill (
In light of these results, I propose two diagnostic exercises to complement the standard test
for differential pre-trends commonly used to detect threats to identification the fraction affected design.
The results for the effective minimum wage design are more concerning. Initially, I demonstrate that two assumptions highlighted by
) are crucial for unbiased estimation of
minimum wage effects on both wages and employment. First, the effective minimum wage
must be constructed using a measure of
of the latent log wage distribution in the
region. An estimator based on a higher quantile of log wage distribution instead of the median suffers from large biases in general. Second, when region-specific distributions of latent
productivities differ both in “location” and “dispersion” parameters, these parameters must
be uncorrelated within periods. This limitation is noteworthy as there are plausible economic
reasons for the existence of such correlations in empirical applications.
Furthermore, I establish that while the assumptions outlined by
they are not sufficient for the validity of the effective minimum wage design. Regional differences in the dispersion parameters alone can introduce economically significant biases.
Detecting these issues can be challenging. While
higher quantiles to assess the design’s validity, I find that this test does not always identify the
new issues I highlight. Moreover, this test is susceptible to false positives, erroneously indicating a problem where none exists. This is because the minimum wage can have substantial
effects on the median wage, implying spillovers into the upper tail of the wage distribution,
even when the impact on employment is minimal (
This paper contributes to the growing literature that points out econometric challenges associated with difference-in-differences designs, both in general and specifically regarding
) discuss the difficulty of detecting longrun minimum wage effects in reduced-form designs.
highlight issues with the effective minimum wage design in the presence of measurement
) raise concerns regarding difference-indifferences designs with heterogeneous treatment effects and non-uniform timing of treatment that are relevant to the effective minimum wage design.
) explore identification challenges when the treatment variable in a
difference-in-differences design is continuous, as is the case with all estimators examined
, for a comprehensive review of recent advances in
the econometrics of difference-in-differences designs). The issues discussed in this paper
complement and differ from those addressed in the aforementioned studies.
The paper is structured as follows. Section 2 introduces the estimators under investigation
and outlines the causal effects of interest. Section 3 presents the economic models and simulation results. Section 4 discusses the econometric issues that give rise to the observed
problems. Finally, the concluding section provides recommendations for researchers interested in measuring the effects of national minimum wage changes.
I consider two-period data generating processes of the following form:

loss of generality, I assume henceforth that
Given this data-generating process, there are two natural ways to define the ceteris paribus
average treatment effects of the national minimum wage:
The first considers a counterfactual where the minimum wage is increased to the level valid
in period 1, keeping other characteristics constant at their
to a counterfactual scenario where the minimum wage remained
at the t = 0 level. The two definitions are identical if the minimum wage is the only timevarying component of the model, and are equal in expectation if the parameters θr,t have
the same distribution across regions in both periods. This is true for some of the models I
study, but not all. To keep the analysis as simple as possible, I use the average of these two
definitions as the “true” causal effects to be recovered by the econometric designs:
which gives equal weight to all observations in the data, and is thus closely related to the
usual definition of average treatment effects in potential outcomes models.
) is fairly general, but it imposes important constraints that limit the scope of my
analysis. First, because equilibrium outcomes in one region cannot affect outcomes in another, this model cannot be used to study econometric issues such as minimum-wage-induced
migration or capital mobility. Second, the restriction to two periods means that I do not address econometric problems arising from the combination of treatment effect heterogeneity
and differential timing of treatment assignment (see
, for a discussion of this issue). Third, I also do not discuss the econometric difficulties associated with distinguishing between short- and long-run minimum wage effects
). Thus, this paper does not aim at providing a
comprehensive account of econometric issues affecting minimum wage designs; instead, the
contribution is pointing out some previously undocumented concerns.
The first estimator I study is a difference-in-differences model with a time-invariant, continuous measure of treatment intensity based on the initial distribution of wages:

The fraction affected design was first introduced by
increase in the federal minimum wage in the US. Card emphasizes that much of the identifying variation in his application comes from significant heterogeneity in the bindingness
of state-level minimum wages in the preceding years. Since that original application, that
estimator has been applied in other contexts with no regional variation in nominal minimum
wages, such as the introduction of a federal minimum wage in Germany in 2015 (
This design is typically employed in scenarios where there is a marked increase in the mini-
mum wage after at least a few years without adjustments. In those cases, the econometrician
can use pre-treatment data to check for differential trends, which may provide support for

The effective minimum wage design has been also used to estimate employment effects;
) is one example. In this case, the model is identical to Equation (
except that the left-hand side contains the employment to population ratio. These regressions
follow in the tradition of earlier papers that used variation in wage levels to measure employment effects of minimum wages. A well-known example is
who use as the treatment variable the nominal minimum wage in a state-year multiplied by
the state-specific minimum wage coverage and divided by the state-specific average wage.
In my analysis, I focus on the quantile-based effective minimum wage because it is more
) discusses the inclusion of region fixed effects in the effective minimum wage
design, arguing that it may not be appropriate in some cases. Thus, in some simulations, I
include models without those fixed effects to evaluate their performance.
This section presents a series of simulation exercises aimed at evaluating whether the estimators described above can recover the true causal effect of an increase in the national
minimum wage. I postpone the discussion of the results—specifically, on why the estimators fail in some cases—to the next section of the paper. Appendix
) argues that this design is subject to bias if there is measurement error
in the benchmark log wage quantile. While this issue may be important in some applications, it is not present
in the simulations in this paper, which do not include measurement error.
The canonical model of labor demand
The first simulations are based on a simple equilibrium model of the labor market, which has
been extensively used to study the evolution of wage inequality in many contexts (e.g.,
, for the US). Consider a competitive economy where the only production
) labor, both of which have inelastic supply. A
representative firm produces the numeraire good in the economy using a constant elasticity
, and the region-specific share of skilled workers
with mean zero and standard deviation

are not employed by the representative firm. That is, the
minimum wage truncates the worker productivity distribution. The equilibrium log prices

percentage points in the employment to population ratio, which is very close to 100% in
the initial period. That is, the employment elasticity with respect to the minimum wage is
In that scenario, the fraction affected design is fairly accurate. On the other hand, the effective minimum wage design (using the median wage as the benchmark) performs poorly,
predicting very strong and positive employment effects and negative wage spillovers for all
measured quantiles. The estimates have low standard errors for both designs.
Panels B and C consider scenarios that differ only in the initial level of the minimum wage.
As it bites more into the latent wage distribution, its truncation effects become stronger, and
so do the endogenous responses in the skill premium
affected captures less than half of the employment loss caused by the minimum wage. It
also underpredicts spillovers at low quantiles and overpredicts at higher quantiles. In Panel
C, even though the employment effects are strongly negative, the fraction affected design
yields a positive point estimate on average. The performance of the effective minimum wage
design is also poor on those panels, though the biases are not as dramatic as in Panel A.
shows simulation results for the same model using alternative estimators
defined in the previous section, such as the Gap measure and the effective minimum wage
using the 90-th percentile as the benchmark. The overall conclusions are similar: all of them
perform poorly, especially the effective minimum wage ones.
One may wonder whether the poor performance of the estimators in the context of the Canonical model depends on the assumption of competitive markets or the endogenous responses
in the skill premium. To shed more light into this issue, this subsection uses an alternative,
flexible model that allows for a range of different scenarios.
has a Normal distribution of latent log wages
. The employment to population ratio and the distribution of observed wages
This model generates both truncation and censoring of the latent wage distribution. Workers
whose latent log wages are below the minimum wage minus the log markdown become
disemployed. Those with latent log wages above the log minimum wage, their observed
wage is equal to the latent wage. Finally, those who remain employed but have latent log
wages below the log minimum wage see a mechanical increase in their wage. The latter
group corresponds to the minimum wage “spike” in the log wage distribution.
The model can be understood as reflecting an economy with inelastic labor supply, exogenous worker productivities, and identical monopsonistic firms paying wages that are below
the marginal products of labor, unless mandated to pay higher wages via the minimum wage.
is low, disemployment effects are smaller and positive effects on

(dispersion) are allowed to change between regions and over time.

Now I proceed to a set of richer simulations to verify the robustness of the estimators in less
stylized scenarios. I start with a baseline scenario where both the location and dispersion
, vary across regions and over time. But importantly, the
are uncorrelated, both in initial levels and in changes. In addition, the changes in each
parameter are uncorrelated with their initial levels. Thus, this scenario intuitively satisfies all
identification assumptions emphasized in existing literature for both estimators: there is no
systematic correlation between location and shape parameters, and no differential trends in
the fundamentals of regions depending on their initial level of minimum wage bindingness.
I choose parameters such that the disemployment effects of minimum wages economically
relevant, but not dramatic (an employment elasticity with respect to the minimum wage of
shows the results of that simulation. As above, the fraction affected has a
small, but economically significant, amount of bias. The effective minimum wage design using the median as the benchmark quantile performs well. However, the one using quantile 0.9
as the benchmark performs poorly, predicting much smaller employment effects and much
bigger spillovers. Indeed, that estimator is strongly biased in all other simulations shown
below. Thus, for the sake of brevity, I will not mention its performance when describing the
In Panel B, I show a modified model that is identical to the baseline, except that the average
dispersion increases from one period to the other. Such changes may reflect, for example,
secular trends in inequality generated by skill-biased technical change, which is believed
to have co-occurred with the decline of the national minimum wage in the US in the 1980’s
, for a single-index model where the dispersion of latent worker
productivities may change over time, applied to the US case). That model still satisfies the
known identification assumptions for both classes of estimators. However, that change from
the baseline scenario is enough to increase the biases for all estimators, especially the fraction
Panel C is similar to the baseline in Panel A, except that it introduces a positive correlation
between the change in location and the change in dispersion between regions. That scenario
could reflect positive demand shocks at the regional level which shift both the average level
of wages and the returns to skill. That shock introduces a correlation between location and
, which violates the main identification assumption emphasized
) for the effective minimum wage design (but often not discussed in other papers
using that strategy). As expected, the effective minimum wage design is strongly biased in
that scenario, predicting smaller disemployment effects and bigger wage spillovers.
. This could happen because initial location may
. This could happen because initial location may
reflect differences in the skill composition of the workforce in a region (as in the canonical
model), and thus mean that factors such as skill-biased technical change may affect them
differently. Alternatively, initial wage levels may correlate with industrial compositions,
making regions subject to different demand shocks coming from e.g., international trade.
shows that this deviation from the baseline model introduces large biases in the fraction affected design, and also in the estimates of spillovers coming from the
The reason why I focus on a correlation between initial location and changes in
instead of changes in location, is because the latter would be an obvious violation of the
parallel trends assumption. It would probably be easy to identify by testing pre-trends (assuming the minimum wage was stable at a low level in the “pre-treatment” years). However,
a differential change in dispersion is more subtle. It would likely not show up in tests for
pre-trends if the outcomes of interest are employment, mean wages, or median wages.
In the final exercise for the Normal-markdown model, I study a scenario with half as much
dispersion in the location parameters (both in levels and in changes) compared to the baseline
in Panel A. That change introduces considerable bias for the effective minimum wage design.
This exercise, presented in Panel E of Table
, suggests that the bias of the effective minimum
wage design depends on the relative amount of “good” variation—quasi-random changes in
the location parameter—compared to other sources of variation in the data. This issue will
be discussed in detail later in the paper.
A task-based, monopsonistic model with two-sided heterogeneity
The previous simulation exercises have two important limitations. First, the causal channels
from the minimum wage to employment and wages are rather limited, excluding margins that
have been shown to be important such as reallocation of workers from low- to high-wage jobs
). Second, they relied on strong functional form assumptions on the
shape of the underlying worker productivity distribution and how it varies across regions and
Task-based, monopsonistic model with two-sided heterogeneity
Effective min. wage, no r FE
This Table compares the true average causal effects of the minimum wage from the model of
) to the predicted average treatment effects from different estimators. The model has 151 regions
(corresponding to microregions in Brazil) and two time periods (corresponding to 1998 and 2012).
To address those limitations, I use the rich model estimated in
data-generating process. In that model, workers belong to one of ten comparative advantage
types, and also differ in their amount of efficiency units of labor within groups. The quantity
of workers of each type is associated with the educational composition of the region at each
period. Firms differ in their demand for skills because they use task-based production technologies, and some firms may have higher demand for high-complexity tasks that are better
performed by skilled workers. Firms also differ in the wages they pay to each worker type;
that is, the model features firm wage premiums. Minimum wages have a range of effects including disemployment (truncation), mechanical wage increases (censoring), between-firm
reallocation, changes in returns to skill within firms, in the distribution of firm types (that
is, the share of high-wage, high-skill firms versus low-wage, low skill ones), in participation decisions of workers, and in prices for goods. Regions differ in not only in educational
composition but also total factor productivity (TFP), three types of labor demand parameters
(which may correlate with TFP and initial educational composition), and some parameters
regulating employment rates (which capture unobserved heterogeneity related to the Brazilian informal sector).
The model is estimated using Brazilian matched employer-employee data, targeting a large
set of moments at the region-time levels. There are 151 regions (corresponding to Brazilian
) and two time periods (corresponding to 1998 and 2012). Appendix Table
shows that the estimated model fits several dimensions of the data pretty well: inequality
measures between and within educational groups, the contribution of firm wage premiums
to inequality (measured using the methodology developed by
), the minimum wage spike, and the share of workers earning up to 30 log points of the
presents the true average causal effects of the increase in the minimum wage in this
model, along with the estimated average treatment effects using the estimators discussed. I
find large biases for all of them. With the exception of the effective minimum wage model
without region fixed effects, all of them under-estimate the substantial disemployment effects of the national minimum wage in Brazil (as implied by the model) by at least 50%. The
effective minimum wage design based on quantile 0.9 predicts positive and statistically significant effects of 2.5 percentage points in the employment to population rate, while the true
effect is a decline of 4.6 percentage points. The estimators also fail to capture the spillover effects on the wage distribution, though the effective minimum wage estimator without region
fixed effects performs surprisingly well in recovering
Discussion: why do the estimators fail?
The simulations show that, in plausible economic scenarios, the estimators may fail to recover the true average causal effects of an increase in the national minimum wage. This
section discusses the econometric issues underlying those failures.
The fraction affected and gap designs
The fraction affected design, and the closely related gap design, have biases in all simulations. Even in the “ideal cases” shown in Table
, and the less problematic case in Tables
, the estimates are often 30% above or below the true average causal effects. If the
econometrician calculates additional statistics based on those simulations, such as dividing
employment effects by wage effects among low-wage workers, the resulting estimate can be
more biased, since the biases in employment and wage effects can go in different directions
(for example, in Panel D of Table
). Those biases do not always go in the same direction,
depending not only on the factors emphasized in the simulations but also others such as the
Thus, the first takeaway from this paper is that even if the design satisfies the parallel trends
assumption and biases are not large, the confidence intervals implied by the estimated standard errors are too strict. Appendix Table
shows that, in the Normal-markdown main
simulations, the estimators incorrectly reject the true causal effect significantly more often
than the nominal 5% rate. Appendix Table
shows that this is true regardless of whether
clustered or robust standard errors are employed.
The core reason why those biases always exist is that the fraction affected (and the gap)
are imperfect proxies of treatment intensity. For a simple illustration, consider a model
where the minimum wage only causes truncation of the latent wage distribution and is the
has latent productivities uniformly distributed over
, and it increases to a higher value
employment and wage effects of the minimum wage differ between regions: for example,
average wages are initially higher in
, but they become identical in period 2. But the fraction
in both regions. So, the fraction affected
design would never be able to recover the true causal effects of the minimum wage in this
This issue is not an artifact of the uniform parameterization. Appendix Table
simulations for a Normal model similar to the one in Panel B of Table
features truncation (that is, there is no markdown,
). With no measurement error in the
model, one could reasonably expect the fraction affected design to yield unbiased estimates
of employment effects, since the workers losing their jobs are precisely the ones “affected”
according to the fraction affected design. Yet, the simulations display significant biases for
One may be tempted to look for changes in functional forms that may could correct this issue.
The problem is that such corrections would depend on assumptions about the data-generating
process. That would eliminate a key advantage of the discussed estimators relative to structural approaches: they allow the researcher to be agnostic about the underlying economic
model and the specific ways the minimum wage may affect outcomes.
As the models become more complex, other issues become relevant. Consider, for example,
a model where regions differ in a location parameters
constant over time, but that the
decreases over time. Suppose that the minimum wage change
is not that large, such that the new minimum is always to left of the peak of the latent log wage
distribution. All else equal, regions with low
a higher fraction affected and a higher causal
effect of the minimum wage. But with the fall in
, these regions may actually see a relative
in employment. That is because as latent wages become more concentrated around
the median, they may become less truncated. This effect may be negligible for regions with
. As a result, the estimator may recover a positive relationship between the fraction
affected and employment, despite the causal effects are negative for all observations in all
periods. This is what happens in Panel B of Table
Some of those problems are likely to be captured by tests for pre-trends. In Appendix Table
, I simulate models identical to those in Table
remains stable at its initial level. Even though the causal effect is zero, the fraction affected
design recovers a positive employment effect in Panel B, capturing the issue described above.
However, this is not guaranteed in all cases where the biases are large. For example, in the
model shown in Panel D of the same table, there is no statistically significant pre-trend on
average. However, it would be possible to detect a problem with the design by checking
for pre-trends in measures of wage dispersion, such as the standard deviation of log wages.
For the Canonical model, pre-trends would not detect any issues with the design, even if
measuring wage dispersion measures. However, Panels
when the biases are large, the estimator incorrectly predicts spillover effects that are flat or
shaped like an inverse U. Thus, evaluating minimum wage impacts at different points of the
wage distribution could provide a test of the plausibility of the estimates from the fraction
For the task-based monopsony estimated using Brazilian data, part of the bias comes from
standard violations of the pre-trends assumption. That’s because changes in educational
achievement, productivity, and demand-side parameters may vary systematically depending
on initial minimum wage bindingness. While these factors could possibly be captured by
pre-trend checks, such checks are not possible in the Brazilian case, because the rise in
the minimum wage is gradual and starts at a time where the country was going through
significant economic reforms. My results thus reinforce the heuristic that, if checking for
pre-trends is not possible, it may not be wise to trust the results of differences-in-differences
Finally, it is worth mentioning that this design is subject to concerns described by
). In that paper, the authors study differencein-difference estimators with a continuous treatment variable. They describe how the parallel
trends assumption needs to be stronger in those models. They also point out that, even when
their “strong parallel trends” assumption holds, the OLS estimator with region and time fixed
effects will not yield the average treatment effect, but instead a weighted average of treatment

With respect to the effective minimum wage design, the first important takeaway from the

The fundamental problem is similar to that in the case of the fraction affected design: the
treatment intensity variable used in the regression does not neatly map into the thought experiment that intuitively identifies the causal effect of interest. Random shocks to location,
uncorrelated with dispersion parameters, provide good variation because they closely correspond to what would happen if all regions where the same, but subject to random changes
in minimum wage bindingness. But suppose that regions differ exclusively in their initial
dispersion parameters and are subject to a national increase in the minimum wage. One can
show that the effective minimum wages changes differentially across regions, and so do outcomes such as employment and wages. However, that scenario does not correspond to the
thought experiment of interest. Correspondingly, the estimated effects of the minimum wage
are completely unrelated to their causal effects. In general, the effective minimum wage
uses both the good and bad variations, and the amount of bias depends of how much good
variation there is relative to the bad.

One important disadvantage of the effective minimum wage design relative the fraction affected/gap ones is that it lacks an effective specification test. The previous discussion shows
that testing for minimum wage effects at the upper tail of the wage distribution may sometimes not detect issues when they exist. Furthermore, there exist compelling theoretical
reasons for why minimum wage effects on the median wage may be more common than
previously thought. One is reallocation of low-wage workers to high-wage firms (
), which can significantly affect median wages in calibrated structural models

I finish this section with two econometric remarks. First,
discussion on whether region fixed effects should be used. In my simulations, I show that
there exist scenarios where it does seem to perform better than other effective minimum
wage estimators. This is particularly true when the outcomes are quantile gaps; see Tables
in the Appendix. The reason is related to the discussion above: omitting the
region fixed effects adds some “good” variation coming from differences in baseline location
Second, I note that my analysis is silent regarding whether one should use models in levels or
in differences, an issue that may matter in implementations of the effective minimum wage
design. The reason is that I focus on two-period models for simplicity, and in those models
the two approaches are equivalent. The discussion in
) suggests that, if those estimators differ substantially, that may be indicative of econometric issues related to treatment effect heterogeneity and the timing of treatment.
In this paper, I showed that commonly used estimators of the effects of national minimum
wages may suffer from previously unknown econometric issues. The fraction affected design, along with the similar gap design, have small biases in general that lead to incorrectly
sized confidence intervals. And in some cases, there may be additional issues that may not
be easily detected via tests for differential pre-trends. In the paper, I suggested two tests that
may detect some of those issues, in addition to the usual check for pre-trends in the main
outcomes of interest. The first suggestion is to check for pre-trends on log wage dispersion
measures, and the second is to evaluate treatment effects for many quantiles of the wage distribution. Researchers may also consider simulation exercises calibrated to their particular
application as a tool to investigate whether the designs are subject to bias and which specific
For the effective minimum wage design, I show that the identification assumptions in
) are necessary and important in practice, but not sufficient. Lee argues that the reference wage used to calculate the effective minimum wage should be a measure of centrality
and that the location and dispersion parameters of latent log wage distributions should not be
correlated across regions. I show that deviations from either assumption leads to severe biases. But I also show that the existence of variation in dispersion parameters between regions
and over time is enough to introduce biases in the estimator, even if they are uncorrelated
My results suggest that, in many applications, neither the fraction affected nor the effective
minimum wage designs may be reliable. In particular, those strategies may not work well
when the increase in the national minimum wage is large, such that it may lead to significant
equilibrium effects through reallocation of labor between firms, changes in returns to skill,
and in the composition of firms operating in the economy. Alternatively, they may also not
work well when the minimum wage increase occurs smoothly over many years, such that
testing for pre-trends is difficult and it becomes more likely that there are trends in latent
productivity dispersion in the study period (caused, e.g., by technical change or international
In those cases, researchers may consider two alternative approaches, while recognizing that
neither is a perfect replacement for a valid quasi-experiment at the local labor market level.
One is to use difference-in-differences designs where the unit of analysis is either firms (
groups are defined based on initial wages in relation to the minimum wage. This approach
